Act1Scene5.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act1Scene5.text: They met me in the day of success, and I have learned by the perfect’st report they have more in them than mortal knowledge missives came from the King, who all-hailed me “Thane of Cawdor,” by which title, before, these Weïrd Sisters saluted me and referred me to the coming on of time with “Hail, king that shalt be.” This have I thought good to deliver thee, my dearest partner of greatness, that thou might’st not lose the dues of rejoicing by being ignorant of what greatness is promised thee. Glamis thou art, and Cawdor, and shalt be What thou art promised. Yet do I fear thy nature; It is too full o’ th’ milk of human kindness To catch the nearest way That I may chastise with the valor of my tongue All that impedes thee from the golden round, Which fate and metaphysical aid doth seem To have thee crowned withal. What is your tidings?
Act1Scene5.translation: I have learned for certain that possess supernatural knowledge...You are too kind to take the shortest route to power...criticize you so that you no longer are affected by what keeps you to take the crown,

Act1Scene5.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act1Scene5.text: Is not thy master with him, who, were ’t so, Would have informed for preparation?

Act1Scene5.speaker: Messenger
Act1Scene5.text: So please you, it is true. Our thane is coming. One of my fellows had the speed of him, Who, almost dead for breath, had scarcely more Than would make up his message.

Act1Scene5.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act1Scene5.text: Give him tending. He brings great news. The raven himself is hoarse That croaks the fatal entrance of Duncan Under my battlements. Come, you spirits That tend on mortal thoughts, unsex me here, And fill me from the crown to the toe top-full Of direst cruelty. Great Glamis, worthy Cawdor, Greater than both by the all-hail hereafter!
Act1Scene5.translation: ... Come here you evil spirits that aid thoughts of murder, remove my womanhood and fill me head to toe with terrible cruelty...

Act1Scene5.speaker: Macbeth
Act1Scene5.text: My dearest love, Duncan comes here tonight.

Act1Scene5.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act1Scene5.text: O, never Shall sun that morrow see! Your face, my thane, is as a book where men May read strange matters. This night’s great business into my dispatch, Which shall to all our nights and days to come Give solely sovereign sway and masterdom.
Act1Scene5.translation: Your face betrays your thoughts so that other can read it like a book.

Act1Scene5.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act1Scene5.text: Leave all the rest to me.
